Apply for an exemption from the second homes premium.

About the second homes premium

From 1 April 2025, most second homes pay a 100% premium on top of the standard council tax charge (200% total).

However, some second homes may be exempt from the premium. This page explains what exemptions are available and how to apply.

Mandatory exemptions (set by law)

The following exemptions are set by law. If your property qualifies, you will automatically be exempt from the second homes premium.

Job-related accommodation

If your employer requires you to live in a property and you're liable for council tax on a second furnished home, you may get a 50% discount on the second home.

You must provide:

  • A letter from your employer confirming the job-related accommodation requirement
  • Your employment contract showing the accommodation requirement
  • Proof that you're liable for council tax on both properties

Annexes

Annexes that are part of, or within the grounds of, a single main home may be exempt from the premium.

The annex must:

  • Be part of a single property or within the grounds
  • Not be anyone's sole or main residence
  • Be used by the household (for example, for guests or family members)

Note: If the annex is let out commercially or used as a separate business, it may not qualify for this exemption.

Armed forces accommodation

Properties owned by serving armed forces personnel who are required to live in military accommodation may be exempt from the premium.

You must provide:

  • Proof of service in the armed forces
  • Evidence that you're required to live in military accommodation
  • Confirmation that the property is not let out commercially

Local discretionary exemptions

Gloucester City Council has also introduced local exemptions in specific circumstances.

Properties actively marketed for sale or let

If your second home is being actively marketed for sale or to let, you may be exempt from the premium for up to 12 months.

You must show that you are:

  • Actively marketing the property at a reasonable market price
  • Using an estate agent or online listing service
  • Making genuine efforts to sell or let the property
  • Accepting reasonable offers

Evidence required:

  • Estate agent or letting agent contract
  • Property listing screenshots showing the property is advertised
  • Evidence of marketing activity (viewings, offers received)
  • Valuation showing the asking price is at market rate

12-month limit: This exemption is granted for up to 12 months. If the property has not sold or let after 12 months, the premium will apply unless you can show exceptional circumstances.

Properties undergoing major renovation

Properties that are genuinely uninhabitable due to major renovation or structural work may be exempt from the premium during the work period.

The work must:

  • Make the property genuinely uninhabitable
  • Be major structural work (not just redecoration)
  • Be actively in progress
  • Have appropriate planning permission or building regulations approval if required

Evidence required:

  • Building contractor invoices
  • Photos showing the extent of work
  • Planning permission or building regulations certificates (if applicable)
  • Projected completion date

Properties in probate

If a property is empty due to the recent death of the owner and probate is being processed, it may be exempt from the premium during the probate period.

You must provide:

  • Death certificate
  • Probate application documentation
  • Evidence that probate is in progress

Note: Once probate is granted and ownership transfers, normal council tax rules apply.

What doesn't qualify for an exemption

The following situations do not qualify for an exemption from the second homes premium:

  • Properties that are simply empty and not being marketed for sale or let
  • Properties used occasionally for holidays or weekends (unless they qualify as a genuine holiday let paying business rates)
  • Properties let to friends or family at below market rates
  • Properties marketed at an unrealistic price to avoid selling
  • Investment properties held for capital appreciation
  • Properties that could be lived in but the owner chooses not to

How to apply for an exemption

To apply for an exemption from the second homes premium:

  1. Check you qualify - Make sure your property meets one of the exemption criteria above
  2. Gather evidence - Collect all the documents listed for your exemption type
  3. Apply online - Use your My Gloucester account to submit your application
  4. Wait for a decision - We'll review your application and contact you within 28 days

Apply for an exemption

You'll need your council tax account reference number.

What evidence you need to provide

All applications must be supported by documentary evidence. The type of evidence depends on which exemption you're applying for.

General evidence requirements

  • Documents must be official and dated
  • We may verify information with third parties (estate agents, employers, etc.)
  • You may be required to provide updated evidence periodically
  • False information may result in prosecution and withdrawal of the exemption

Evidence for the 12-month marketing exemption

For the actively marketed exemption, you must provide:

  • Estate agent contract showing the property is listed for sale or let
  • Property listing screenshots from Rightmove, Zoopla, or other platforms
  • Independent valuation showing your asking price is at market rate
  • Marketing activity log (viewings, offers, enquiries)

We will check that the property is genuinely available and that the price is realistic. Properties marketed at significantly above market value to avoid selling will not qualify.

Review and appeals

If your application is approved

If we approve your exemption, we'll write to confirm:

  • The start date of the exemption
  • How long the exemption will last
  • What you need to do to maintain the exemption
  • When you need to provide updated evidence

If your application is refused

If we refuse your exemption application, we'll explain why. You can:

  • Ask us to review the decision if you have new evidence
  • Contact us to discuss your circumstances
  • Appeal to the Valuation Tribunal if you believe the decision is wrong

Need help with your application? Contact our Council Tax team on 01452 396396 or email revenues@gloucester.gov.uk

Your ongoing obligations

If your exemption is approved, you must:

  • Tell us about changes - Inform us if your circumstances change (for example, if you stop marketing the property)
  • Provide updates - Give us updated evidence when we ask for it
  • Maintain the qualifying criteria - Continue to meet the exemption requirements
  • Renew if required - Some exemptions need to be renewed annually

Warning: If you fail to notify us of changes or provide false information, we may withdraw the exemption and charge you backdated council tax plus the premium. We may also prosecute for fraud.

Second homes premium

100% premium from April 2025

This means second homes pay 200% of the standard charge, unless they qualify for an exemption.
